There are two types of readers in this world:

Those who love to read Neil Gaiman, and those who haven't discovered him...yet.

OK, I exaggerate. But Neil is so crafty, so clever, so careful with language, that there's probably something for everyone. I'm not wild about everything he has written, but I can always admire how he does it.

This compendium has 47 short stories and short excerpts (10 pages or so) from his novels. A couple of the stories tie into his novel ‚ÄúAmerican Gods‚Äù and one ties to ‚ÄúN
I need this more than I think I've ever needed anything in my entire life.
I received a free, advanced copy from NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

This is a hefty read, but it‚Äôs one that can be taken in bits and pieces, a short story here and a shorter one there. Every bit is wonderful, from Gaiman‚Äôs earliest works to those from the past few years. A few of them, such as ‚ÄúThe Sleeper and the Spindle‚Äù and ‚ÄúHow to Talk to Girls at Parties‚Äù have grown into other forms beyond a short story, but they are absolutely fantastic in their original form.
This collection is well suited for anyone from a Neil Gaiman novice to a reader who‚Äôs been follow
As with all collections a bit uneven, and tastes will vary, but overall a fascinating collection of the weird, the ghostly and the unnerving.

Here is the recipe for this compilation:

1) Add together the contents of Smoke and Mirrors, Fragile Things and Trigger Warning collections
2) Subtract from the sum all those nice introductions to individual short stories
3) Subtract some weaker stories
4) Subtract all the pieces of poetry
5) Add (completely unnecessary) extracts from the novels by Neil Gaiman
6) Add a short story I, Cthulhu that you can read for free on Neil Gaiman's web-site
7) Add a short story Mythical Creatures (2008)
8) Add a short

This is an enormous assortment of Neil Gaiman's writings dating from 1984 to 2018, including excerpts of five novels. Gaiman himself has said this is primarily intended as a sampler for readers who aren't familiar with his work. It seems like quite a hefty time investment for someone who just wants to try this Gaiman bloke people seem to like so much, but I hope it works. Leaning toward 3.5. After I accepted Oates' apparent definition of 'suspense" I was ok with the stories if a bit disappointed. What I struggled with was how they featured various women -- Clare, Mia, Alyce, and Elisabeth -- all victims; they were either naive or foolishly lured by the pretense of love, too weak each time. Too often the protagonists went unpunished and the tragedies were seen as "Not his fault, but hers."

I absolutely adore Joyce Carol Oates and her way of making real life tragedies terrifying. Her stories, especially her short stories, are so magnificent to read or listen to. While they tend to have just a pinch of supernatural, the truly creepy aspects of her writing bring to life things that happen to so many people, on a daily basis. She is one of the few writers who can make every day things scary, but in such a beautifully written way.

I always enjoy books by this author. This book was no different. I enjoyed the characters and the mini stories. I don't always agree with what I personally find are some stereotypes of gender and gender relations but I enjoyed the stories. I cannot say that this was my favorite most entertaining book of the summer but overall I enjoyed it. Thank you to NetGalley for the advanced reader copy.

All of these short novels are so atmospheric, feel so true to human nature, yet are so perfect at building psychological terror that I was aware of my increased heart rate when nearing the end of each of them. Great reading experience thanks to an exceptional author.

Thanks to NetGalley and Mysterious Press for the ARC to read and review.

Wow! You've done it again. I love the places your writing takes me and though dark, it brings such things to light. I don't know where it comes from but keep writing for as long as I am alive. I look forward to our journeys. There isn't a favorite over the four stories in this book. Each one feels wonderful in their unique way.

Audio. I really liked the first novella. The others were fine if a bit predictable. This collection would likely not have been published by a lesser known author. The stories seem tossed off, which is my primary disappointment with Oates. I always expect more insight and instead it's just storytelling. Which is fine but a bit disappointing.

I've never read Joyce Carol Oates and I really like her writing style. These four novellas were so unique, even though each had a female victim as its central character and each had a surprising ending. An excellent read for the month of October, this won't be my last by this talented author.

4 stars

This was a haunting series of stories by Joyce Carol Oates. I love that she can take a story and turn it on it's head to something resonant and utterly beguiling at the same time. These four stories really exemplify the utter craft of this author. Thanks for the ARC, Net Galley.

I received an ARC of this collection of novellas from Netgalley in exchange for an honest review.

I love the stories of Joyce Carol Oates. Her raw portrayals of life and the ugliness alongside the beauty and hopefulness of existence is compelling.

What can I say that will do these stories justice? This is a book of 4 novellas/short stories as only JCO is able to do. Each story is better than the rest!

My thanks to Netgalley and Grove Atlantic for this advanced readers copy. This book is due to release on October 6, 2020.

Surprisingly this is my first book by Oates I've read. And reading short stories is even more out of my comfort zone.
Each of these stories has just the right amount of suspense to make you want to curl up with blanket and hot tea during a thunderstorm with this book.

Thanks NetgGalley!

Four well-written novellas in Oates‚Äôs remarkable melancholy, almost gothic, style when writing suspense. Coincidentally in the same order in the book as my ‚Äúranking‚Äù of them. All, as with many novellas, seemed to end before the story is truly finished.

This woman can write a great story but this one just wasn‚Äôt my cup of tea! I really enjoyed just two out of the four novellas! And one, for me was not even suspenseful! That‚Äôs my opinion and I‚Äôll wait for the next JCO to be released.

I listened to the audiobook of Cardiff, bye the Sea: Four Novellas of Suspense. As far as the narration goes, the narrator did a good job creating distinct characters. However, this book was not for me. I found the stories depressing and slow.

Outstanding, outstanding, outstanding! Four novellas that are among Ms Oates finest. As soon as you begin to read each one, you cannot stop, and you don‚Äôt want them to end.
It‚Äôs difficult to put into words how extraordinary the writing is.

Thanks to Negalley and the publisher for the opportunity to review.

I listened to the audio version of this and while the narrator was not my favorite, I enjoyed the creepy, erie novellas. The stories were the perfect length and a perfect listen for this time of year.
I am a huge Joyce Carol Oates fan but this book is just awful. The stories contained within in are stilted and disjointed and best and horrible at worst. Give this a pass
I received an ARC of this book. It was not my cup of tea, unfortunately. I haven't read much else by JCO, so perhaps this would be adored by her fans.
Check back for my full review on the New York Journal of Books.
Constant creepy sensation as I read, perfect for autumn and Halloween!

Terrifically average. Any comparison to Edgar Allan Poe is completely undeserved. Not even close. Nothing scary in these stories at all.
This is a wonderful collection of stories. Not to be missed.
WOW! The language in this book is so precise and perfect that you will want to go back and read it over and over again.
I enjoyed the first 3 novellas but the final one did not hold my interest and I ended up skimming to the end. The author is very adept at building suspense.
I‚Äôm usually not interested in Story Collections but this one was fantastic! Each story was captivating and mysterious ... hard to put down.
Our most prolific author never disappoints. Three great stories. I especially enjoyed Miao Dao.
Great read(s)!
All around great compilation of creepy, scary novellas.
All four novellas were amazing. I especially loved Miao Diao and Cardiff, by the sea. Joyce Carol Oates is an excellent mystery/thriller/horror writer.
actually 3.5 rounded to 4 stars. The novella and three short stories are what I would expect from JCO. Good reads. Eerie and weird.
I'm not much of a short-story reader. But for Joyce Carol Oates, I'll read anything. These four short stories are chilling.
Not my kind of suspense.
Joan Didion is a great writer, this is four short stories.

Thanks to the publisher and Netgalley for granting me an advance review copy.

not for me
Each of these four novellas is suspenseful and gripping. I was eager to return to reading them every night.

Four horror novellas in one beautifully narrated audiobook. Amazing, exceptional, and impossible to put down. Some stories gave me chills, some made me break down in tears, some made me chuckle, and most left me unsettled and reflective. Great collection of diverse authors and stories. I really really really hope there will be a second volume.
Tiny Nightmares has a selection of fantastic scary, creepy, unsettling stories. I enjoyed many of them and the collection as a whole was well thought out.

There wasn't a clunker in this high quality collection of 40+ very very short stories. What a quirky, spooky, fun, and yes in some cases nightmare inducing collection of tales perfect for October or really anytime!

This was a fun read with stories that ranged from amusing to macabre to downright horrifying.

A wonderful collection of short stories filled with nightmares. I had such a fun time reading each and every one of these little horror stories. I really liked the sense of dread built into each story separately and how it accumulated into one cohesive collection. Reading this was like watching tiny horror shorts and I loved every second of it. The stories were fun to read and this was such a good time!

Obviously in short story collections, some stories are better than others. However, what‚Äôs unique about this series is not only the shortness of the stories but the diversity of its themes. Each story is about a ‚Äúnightmare‚Äù scenario. And what that means is entirely up to the author, thus giving readers a vast array of horror, twisted realism, science fiction, psychological, etc fiction.

A collection of horror-inspired flash fiction, Tiny Nightmares is a playful, spine-tingling collection, where leading literary and horror writers spin unforgettably chilling tales in only a few pages.
More like a 3.5. As with any story collection, there were some great ones and some that didn‚Äôt land with me, but overall a great dip into short form horror.

Overall- I think what I really liked about this was the way that Philyaw moved between how the women (and men) in the story were at church and then all the other six days of the week when they‚Äôre seemingly other people.

Short stories about African American women; their friends, family, and church. Each story is about sex, almost always adulterous. Church plays a significant role in each story, usually as a way to point out hypocrisy.
Eula. Two women enjoy an annual New Years tryst in a motel room.
Not-Daniel. Two strangers, a man and a woman, both visiting their mothers in the Hospice center, both from out of town, have a tryst in a car.
Dear Sister. Adult women sisters, gathered for the funeral of their philander

I must confess, I HATE THIS COVER. Now with that out of the way, these are some of the richest stories I have read in years. So much love shown to the 40+ women! The shout outs to the Young & the Restless, Dynasty, Falcon Crest, Knots Landing and Dallas brought back so many memories. For those of us who grew up during the 80s and 90s, we know how iconic these shows are among our mothers and grandmothers.

"Secret Lives of Church Ladies" was different to what I expected, but I certainly enjoyed reading it. The collection was short enough to read in one sitting yet the stories themselves were the perfect length. I ought to have inferred more from the title but I didn't expect there to be quite so many intimate revelations. Well-written.

Clever and true. The characters voices in these stories come through vividly. Each of these stories is unique, though they sometimes explore similar themes: sexuality, complicated family relationships, and ties to faith. My favorite story was Jael. The two characters - Jael and her Granny - are so distinct and exquisitely rendered, I would love to read an entire novel about them.

Storytelling at it's best! A unique collection of stories that grab your attention and keep you reading, wanting more from each story told. A book you will want to recommend at book club and an even better gift to give to a friend in a book slump. The nomination for the national book award in fiction was well deserved. My first read from Mrs. Philyaw but definitely not my last.

This collection of stories really spoke to me. I could hear the voices of many women in my life in these pages that represent life for black women of a certain age. The pain, loneliness, and humor are all here. Each story is well crafted and totally unpredictable. I was so happy to see that it made the shortlist of for the National Book Award - it is a well deserved honor.

I don't tend to read short stories, but I'll pick up almost anything recommended by the National Book Award folks. I loved this collection! It felt very cross-cultural: religion is not part of my life, lots of views of the Southern experience and Black lives that I am not often privy to. But also flashes of recognition that made it all relatable on one level or another.

This was a wonderful collection of stories about 4 generations of black women. The stories illuminated issues of race, gender, class, sexuality, addiction, poverty, relationships and parenthood. Some of the stories were sad, some were raw and painful, some were joyful, but I was glad to have read them all.

I‚Äôve never been one for a collection of short stories but if they are anything like this one, I‚Äôm a new convert.
